resources.string: Pain Relief Exercises

This app is not a medical professional, but it can provide general information on exercises to get relief from your pain. Consult a healthcare professional before starting any new exercise program, especially with pre-existing health conditions, for personalized advice.

Generally, for each exercise, you can start with 8–12 repetitions (reps) and gradually increase as you become more comfortable. It is important to listen to your body, and if you experience any pain or discomfort, you should stop the exercise.
Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Tighten your abdominal muscles and push your lower back into the floor. Hold for a few seconds and then relax. Repeat.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips toward the ceiling, creating a straight line from your shoulders to your knees. Hold for a few seconds and then lower your hips. Repeat.
Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position. Arch your back (like a cat) and then gently curve it downward (like a cow). Repeat the movement in a flowing manner.
Kneel on the floor with your toes together and knees apart. Sit back on your heels and reach your arms forward, lowering your chest towards the floor.
Lie on your back with knees bent. Bring one knee up towards your chest, holding it with both hands. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.
Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Cross your arms over your chest and lift your shoulders off the floor.
Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position. Extend your right arm forward and left leg back, keeping your back straight. Hold for a few seconds and then switch sides.
Lie face down on the floor with arms and legs extended. Lift your right arm and left leg simultaneously, then switch sides in a swimming motion.
1. Neck Stretches

Gently tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear towards your shoulder. Hold for 15–30 seconds and repeat on the other side. Slowly rotate your head in a circular motion, both clockwise and counterclockwise. Do this for 15–30 seconds in each direction.
2. Neck Rotation
Turn your head to one side, bringing your chin over your shoulder. Hold for 15–30 seconds and repeat on the other side.
3. Neck Flexion and Extension

Gently tilt your head backward, looking up at the ceiling. Hold for 15–30 seconds. Return to the neutral position and then gently tilt your head forward, bringing your chin towards your chest. Hold for 15–30 seconds.
4. Shoulder Rolls
Roll your shoulders in a circular motion, both forward and backward, to release tension in the neck and upper back.
5. Chin Tucks
Sit or stand with a straight spine. Tuck your chin towards your chest, creating a double chin. Hold for a few seconds and then release. Repeat several times.
6. Shoulder Blade Squeezes
Sit or stand with a straight spine. Squeeze your shoulder blades together, as if you are trying to hold a pencil between them. Hold for a few seconds and then relax. Repeat several times.
1. Pendulum Stretch
While standing, lean forward and support your non-affected arm on a table or chair. Allow your affected arm to hang down and gently swing it in a circular motion.
2. Wall Crawl
Stand facing a wall and place your fingertips on the wall at chest height. Walk your fingers up the wall, reaching as high as you comfortably can. Slowly walk your fingers back down.
3. Shoulder Blade Squeeze
Sit or stand with your back straight. Squeeze your shoulder blades together, holding for a few seconds. Repeat several times.
4. External Rotation with a Band
Attach a resistance band to a doorknob at waist height. Hold the other end with your affected arm. Keep your elbow at a 90-degree angle and rotate your arm outward against the resistance.
5. Scapular Retraction
Sit or stand with your arms at your sides. Squeeze your shoulder blades together without shrugging your shoulders. Hold for a few seconds and release.
1. Wrist Flexor Stretch:

Extend your arm in front of you with the palm facing down. Gently use your opposite hand to pull back on your fingers, stretching the wrist extensors. Hold for 15–30 seconds and repeat on the other hand.
2. Wrist Extensor Stretch:
Extend your arm with the palm facing up. Gently pull back on your fingers with your opposite hand to stretch the wrist flexors. Hold for 15–30 seconds and repeat on the other hand.
3. Wrist Circles:
Rotate your wrists in circular motions, both clockwise and counterclockwise. Perform 10–15 circles in each direction.
4. Wrist Tendon Gliding:
Start with your hand in a neutral position. Flex your fingers down and then extend them while keeping the wrist in a neutral position. Repeat this gliding motion for 10–15 repetitions.
5. Wrist Eccentric Exercise with a Light Weight:
Hold a light weight (like a small dumbbell or a water bottle) in your hand with the palm facing down. Slowly lower the weight by extending your wrist. Perform 10–15 repetitions.
3. Forearm Pronation and Supination

Hold a light dumbbell or a similar object in your hand, with your elbow bent at 90 degrees. Rotate your forearm, turning your palm up (supination) and then down (pronation). Perform 2–3 sets of 15–20 repetitions on each arm.
4. Wrist Eccentric Exercises

Use a light resistance band or a small weight (1–2 pounds). Sit or stand with your forearm supported, wrist hanging off the edge. Slowly lower the wrist down and then lift it back up using the unaffected hand. Perform 2–3 sets of 15–20 repetitions.
5. Isometric Wrist Contractions
Make a fist and place a rolled–up towel or a small ball in your hand. Squeeze the fist for 5–10 seconds, then release. Repeat for 2–3 sets of 10–15 repetitions.
6. Triceps Stretch
Reach your hand down your back, palm facing your spine. Use your opposite hand to gently push on your bent elbow. Hold for 15–30 seconds and repeat on both arms.
1. Hip Flexor Stretch

Kneel on your right knee with your left foot in front, forming a 90–degree angle. Lean forward, keeping your back straight, until you feel a stretch in the front of your right hip. Hold for 15–30 seconds and switch sides.
2. Seated Butterfly Stretch
Sit on the floor, bringing the soles of your feet together. Hold your feet with your hands and gently press your knees toward the floor.
3. Inner Thigh Lifts
Lie on your side with your bottom leg bent and your top leg straight. Lift your top leg a few inches off the ground and hold for a few seconds. Lower the leg back down. Repeat on both sides.
4. Clamshell Exercise

Lie on your side with your knees bent and stack on top of each other. Keep your feet together and lift your top knee while keeping your feet in contact. Lower the knee back down. Repeat on both sides.
5. Pelvic Tilts
Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Tighten your abdominal muscles and press your lower back into the floor. Hold for a few seconds and then release.
6. Bridge Exercise

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips toward the ceiling, creating a straight line from shoulders to knees. Hold for a few seconds and then lower your hips back down.
2. Piriformis Stretch

Sit on the floor with one leg bent and the other crossed over, placing the foot on the outside of the bent knee. Twist your torso toward the bent knee while supporting your weight with your hands. Hold for 15–30 seconds and switch sides.
3. Hip Abduction Exercise

Lie on your side with the bottom leg straight and the top leg bent at a 90–degree angle. Lift the bottom leg toward the ceiling, keeping it straight. Lower it back down without letting it touch the other leg. Do 2 sets of 10–15 repetitions on each side.
5. Leg Raises
Lie on your back and lift one leg at a time, keeping it straight. Lower the leg back down without letting it touch the ground. Do 2 sets of 10–15 repetitions on each leg.
1. Quad Sets
Sit on the floor with your legs extended. Tighten the muscles on the top of your thigh and push the back of your knee down into the floor. Hold for a few seconds, then relax. Repeat several times.
2. Straight Leg Raises
Sit or lie down with your back straight. Lift your leg straight in front of you without bending the knee. Hold for a few seconds and then lower it slowly. Repeat with the other leg.
3. Hamstring Curls
Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Bend one knee and bring your heel toward your buttocks. Hold for a few seconds, then slowly lower your leg. Repeat with the other leg.
4. Wall Squats
Stand with your back against a wall. Slide down into a squatting position, keeping your back against the wall. Hold for 10–20 seconds and then slowly slide back up.
5. Calf Raises
Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Rise up on your toes, lifting your heels off the ground. Hold for a moment, then lower your heels back down.
6. Partial Squats
Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Perform a partial squat by bending your knees slightly. Make sure your knees don not go past your toes. Hold for a few seconds and then straighten up.
7. Step-Ups
Use a sturdy step or platform. Step up with one foot and then bring the other foot up. Step back down with the leading foot. Repeat, alternating the leading foot.
